text: what research shows us is that we very
quickly in milliseconds sex categorize
any person that we interact with be it
in person or whether we interact with
their resume or anything else and the
problem with that is that once we sex
categorize someone once we take notice
that they're male or female then this
affects the expectations that we have
about that individual whereby we if we
notice someone's a man we expect him to
be more like men in general are which
includes being a gentle kappa Belov
getting things done I'm risk-taking if
you will we do this just instantly
better at male type tasks if we notice
someone's a woman by contrast and we
expect her to perhaps be more communal
more concerned about others better at
female type tasks and certainly not
assertive or dominant so these
expectations form this in turn leads to
a bias and how we process information
such that the very same performance if
it's offered by a man tends to in most
situations look more competent more
capable than if a woman had offered that
same performance a lot of bias training
comes in and tries to raise people's
awareness about the way that bias works
in the organization and we think that
that is a necessary step but not it's
not sufficient that we need to go a step
further so our model does not rely
solely on people policing their own
decision-making to make sure they're not
being biased instead it says okay here
we've established some patterns how can
we change work okay what can we change
in terms of our work processes to make
the incidence of bias less likely to
occur in the first place the company
that we're working with currently the
first thing they wanted to do was to
collect some data on the kinds of
language that was used in performance
evaluations they were worried that bias
might be creeping in there and our early
analysis show they were right there is a
sort of a gendered way of talking about
men and women that's potentially
disadvantaging to women if we think that
one of the disadvantages that women are
facing is that they're not when they're
described in terms of performance
evaluations they're not described in the
kind of agentic way that would get them
promoted the short term win is to see a
change in that language okay so you can
see that you know I think pretty pretty
quickly a medium-term win for us is to
start to see that internal survey data
that companies
collect I'm that the bias that those
surveys find starts to be reduced so
you're changing things in the broader
culture and then ultimately we want to
see the numbers move if you're a person
trying to bring about change and you
have to credo solve world hunger or
eliminate poverty or something like that
you're not going to want to get out of
bed in the morning right that's just too
too big so is there something that we
can see along the way that allows us to
feel like we're making change and
increase our sense of efficacy and we
believe if we can do that if we can get
people involved in the solutions and
allow them to see that they're making
progress that this will create contagion
that is that you start to solve one
problem and you come to see yourself as
someone who is actually able to solve
all kinds of problems if we can create
change agents that's going to allow
change to be more sustainable and it's
also going to mean that even if
leadership at the top changes if you've
got people that feel empowered they are
still going to be able to make some
progress in that organization
